bestBHT.bht: This consequence of establishing the law demonstrates that Abraham, the father and head of the race, was justified not by works but by faith. The question is whether Abraham was justified by anything that pertained to the flesh, by his own efforts or legal obedience, and the answer is that he found acceptance with God through faith, not carnal reason. By using Abraham's example, the Jews were reminded not to trust in their own righteousness by the law.

Henry Alford: This verse, and the argument following, are not a proof, but a consequence, of we establish the law..." (15 words)
And the question is not one which requires any such distinction between his fleshly and spiritual paternity..." (20 words)
...to shew that the father and head of the race himself was justified not by works but by faith." (16 words)
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Abraham, our father as pertaining to the flesh, hath found?
Hath found, as pertaining to ('according to,' or 'through') the flesh
By all his natural efforts or legal obedience
Albert Barnes: The object of the apostle now is to answer this inquiry.
The Jews valued themselves much on the fact that he was their father; and an argument, drawn from his example or conduct, therefore, would be especially forcible.
If people are justified by faith; if works are to have no place; if, therefore, all rites and ceremonies, all legal observances, are useless in justification; what is the advantage of circumcision?
Marvin Vincent: What shall we say? The phrase anticipates an objection or proposes an inference. It is used by Paul only, and by him only in this Epistle and in its argumentative portions." (Quote 1)
Found signifies, attained by his own efforts apart from grace." (Quote 2)
The question is, Was Abraham justified by anything which pertained to the flesh?" (Quote 3)
John Calvin: In many other things one example would not be sufficient to make a common rule; but as in the person of Abraham there was exhibited a mirror and pattern of righteousness, which belongs in common to the whole Church...
Since it is then evident that he was justified freely, his posterity, who claimed a righteousness of their own by the law, ought to have been made silent even through shame.
He then concedes to the Jews a closer bond of union, but only for this end — that he might more deeply impress them that they ought not to depart from the example of their father.
Philip Schaff: What shall we say then that Abraham our forefather hath found (i.e., attained) according to the flesh (i.e., through his own natural efforts as distinct from the grace of God).
The opposite would be ‘according to the Spirit,’ according to the working of the Spirit of God.
Archibald T. Robertson: Forefather. Old word...only here in N.T."
Hath found...perfect active infinitive...in indirect discourse.
John Gill: The apostle having proved that there is no justification by the works of the law; to make this appear more clear and evident to the Jews, he instances in the greatest person of their nation, and for whom they had the greatest value and esteem."
The sense of the whole is, did he find out the way of life, righteousness, and salvation by the mere hint of carnal reason? and did he obtain these things by his own strength?"
It is evident from what follows, that the meaning of the apostle is, that it should be understood in the negative.
John Wesley: That our father Abraham hath found — Acceptance with God.
According to the flesh — That is, by works.

bhtAttempts.bht: This verse is not a proof, but a consequence, of establishing the law, showing that the father and head of the race, Abraham, was justified not by works but by faith. The question being asked is whether Abraham was justified by anything that pertained to the flesh, by his own efforts or legal obedience. This question anticipates an objection or proposes an inference, and the answer is that Abraham found acceptance with God not by the mere hint of carnal reason, but through faith. The purpose of using Abraham's example is to impress upon the Jews that they should not depart from the example of their father and trust in their own righteousness by the law.

This consequence of establishing the law illustrates that Abraham, the father and head of the race, was justified not by works but by faith. The question asked is whether Abraham was justified by anything that pertained to the flesh, by his own efforts or legal obedience. It anticipates an objection or proposes an inference, and the answer is that Abraham found acceptance with God not by carnal reason, but through faith. By using Abraham's example, the Jews were reminded not to trust in their own righteousness by the law.

This consequence of establishing the law demonstrates that Abraham, the father and head of the race, was justified not by works but by faith. The question is whether Abraham was justified by anything that pertained to the flesh, by his own efforts or legal obedience, and the answer is that he found acceptance with God through faith, not carnal reason. By using Abraham's example, the Jews were reminded not to trust in their own righteousness by the law.

The question posed is whether Abraham was justified by anything that pertained to the flesh, by his own efforts or legal obedience. The answer is that Abraham found acceptance with God through faith, not carnal reason. By using Abraham's example, the Jews were reminded not to trust in their own righteousness by the law.

The mention of Abraham in this verse serves to illustrate the consequence of establishing the law, that he was justified not by works but by faith. The question asked is whether Abraham was justified by anything that pertained to the flesh, which refers to his own efforts or legal obedience. Through faith, Abraham attained acceptance with God, not relying on carnal reason. This example of Abraham is intended to caution the Jews against trusting in their own righteousness by the law.
